snippet: People flooding into Europe, and an inability to accommodate them in an organized way, may be starting to fray a commitment to erase old borders.
abstract: Flood of migrants seeking asylum in Europe is straining European Union's commitment to open borders and passport-free travel between its states; member states are struggling to organize their response, while increased inspections of vehicles and trains for smuggled migrants have led to travel delays; German Chancellor Angela Merkel has warned unfettered travel may be endangered without unified plan to deal with crisis.

byline.original: By ALISON SMALE and MELISSA EDDY
byline.contributor: Alison Smale reported from Vienna, and Melissa Eddy from Berlin. Palko Karasz contributed reporting from Budapest, and Rick Gladstone from New York.

lead_paragraph: People flooding into Europe, and an inability to accommodate them in an organized way, may be starting to fray a commitment to erase old borders.

headline.main: Migrant Crisis Tests Core European Value: Open Borders
headline.print_headline: Crisis Tests European Core Value: Open Borders

keywords.name: subject
keywords.value: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
